Detailed Description

The ISkeleton class serves as an interface to the Skeleton class which is a data structure containing the tracked rotation and translation data, as well as the bounding region for each joint.

Once the MotionSensor object has been instantiated and initialized, you can get the full body skeleton. The SDK keeps a Skeleton object in memory and updates it per frame based on changes in the scene.

The 3D positions and rotations for the following joints can be queried per frame: • Head • Torso • Center of hips • Tips of both hands • Elbows • Shoulders • Knees • Neck • Collar bones • Waist • Left and right hips • Spine joints • Left and right feet

Note:
The Skeleton class contains both accessors and mutators. Use mutators only when creating your own skeleton, of for overriding certain data, as they will overwrite data read from the sensor/sequence.

virtual OMKStatus Omek::ISkeleton::getJointConfidence ( JointID  id,
unsigned int &  confidence 
) const [pure virtual]

Get confidence measure for specific joint.

The confidence of a joint is a percentage measure of how confident the tracking algorithm is of a result of tracking that specific joint. For example, when a joint is occluded, its confidence drops to a lower value. Similarly, confidence drops to a low value when a joint is outside of the sensor's field of view.

Parameters:
[in]idThe id of this joint
[out]confidenceResultant confidence measure (0-100)
Returns:
OMK_SUCCESS for success, an error code otherwise
virtual JointID Omek::ISkeleton::getJointId ( unsigned int  index) const [pure virtual]

Return the joint id in the specific index

Parameters:
[in]indexthe index of the wanted joint, useful for iterating through all joints in this skeleton
